title: Labor to take RET of 50pc by 2030 to national conference
text:
Federal Opposition Leader Bill Shorten: "We will take steps to reduce pollution, and we will not be intimidated by ridiculous scare campaigns." Justin McManus Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan The solar industry is celebrating after Labor revealed a new policy to increase the percentage of Australia's large-scale energy production made up by renewables to 50 per cent by 2030.
The full plan will be revealed at the party's national conference and if enacted, the new goal could mean a doubling of the renewables sector.
Previously both the Coalition and Labor were committed to the current benchmark of a minimum 33,000 gigawatt hours of renewable energy by 2020 - or a target of about 23.5 per cent of power generated by renewables by that date.
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten said the move demonstrated Labor would "not be intimidated" by Coalition scare campaigns over carbon pricing, after a damaging leak of their draft emissions trading scheme.
"We will take steps to reduce pollution, and we will not be intimidated by ridiculous scare campaigns," Mr Shorten said.
Incoming ALP president and shadow environment spokesman Mark Butler said: "we think 50 per cent is an ambitious but do-able goal".
The goal is also a step up on the policy Labor took to the 2010 election of 40 per cent of power generation made up by renewables by 2050.
Last week, Labor confirmed it is also working on a new emissions trading scheme to take to the next election, after a damaging leak.
 The leaked documents laid out a proposal, not yet been considered by shadow cabinet, for one scheme for the electricity industry and another one for the rest, which Mr Butler said would not be a carbon tax.
At the conference the new renewables target will be accompanied by a commitment not to introduce a fixed price on carbon.
"History proves that Australians do not want a carbon tax," Jason Clare, Shadow Minister for Communications, said commenting on the plan on Wednesday.
Good news for the solar industry The Australian Solar Council s aid it "strongly welcomes" the announcement, saying it was "a huge win for the solar industry".
Mr Butler said while it was important the government did not "pick winners" among renewable technology, but research was convincing him of the power of solar technology.
He said it was "continuing to take off" considering improvements in batteries and storage technology.
Climate Institute Deputy head, Erwin Jackson, said that going forward bipartisan agreement on these targets would be needed to keep global capital and clean energy investors in Australia.
But he said the new policy "recognises that to remain competitive with other countries we must modernise and clean up our old, high emission and inefficient power sector," he said.
Chief executive of the Climate Institute, John Connor, said while he saw it as a significant step, but was concerned about the rest of the energy mix.
"The devil is always in the detail. What happens to the other 50 per cent is important. If that is just brown coal then we're still in trouble," he said.
The ALP national conference will be held in Melbourne from Friday to Sunday.
